elements.content: Reactions in water of 4,5-dichlorophthalate (dcpa2–) with the heaviest lanthanide ions lead to a family of compounds with the general chemical formula [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞, where Ln = Tb–Lu, Y. The synthesis, crystal structure, thermal behavior, and luminescent properties of this series of homonuclear compounds are described. Additionally, this family can be extended to isostructural heteronuclear compounds that can contain some light lanthanide ions and therefore present some original photophysical properties. These compounds show potential interest as multiemissive materials (visible and infrared light between 450 and 1600 nm) and could find application as luminescent bar codes.
elements.clean_text: Reactions in water of 4,5-dichlorophthalate (dcpa2-) with the heaviest lanthanide ions lead to a family of compounds with the general chemical formula [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞, where Ln = Tb-Lu, Y. The synthesis, crystal structure, thermal behavior, and luminescent properties of this series of homonuclear compounds are described. Additionally, this family can be extended to isostructural heteronuclear compounds that can contain some light lanthanide ions and therefore present some original photophysical properties. These compounds show potential interest as multiemissive materials (visible and infrared light between 450 and 1600 nm) and could find application as luminescent bar codes.

elements.content: The reaction in water of 4,5-dichlorophthalate (dcpa2−) with lanthanide ions leads to a family of isostructural homo- or hetero-lanthanide-based coordination polymers isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞. Some of these compounds exhibit bright and highly tunable luminescence in both visible and infrared domains and could be of interest as luminescent bar codes.
elements.clean_text: The reaction in water of 4,5-dichlorophthalate (dcpa2-) with lanthanide ions leads to a family of isostructural homo- or hetero-lanthanide-based coordination polymers isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞. Some of these compounds exhibit bright and highly tunable luminescence in both visible and infrared domains and could be of interest as luminescent bar codes.

elements.content: For more than a decade, there has been growing interest in lanthanide-based coordination compounds, particularly because of their interesting optical properties. Our group, which has been involved in that field for almost 20 years, has currently focused its attention on luminescent heterolanthanide coordination polymers that could be used as taggants for the fight against counterfeiting. Evidently, because technological applications are targeted, ligands must be commercially available, have low cost, and be thermally stable and nontoxic. Moreover, the production process must be respectful of the environment. Therefore, we have investigated numerous benzenepolycarboxylate ligands in association with lanthanide ions, with the aim of bright and highly tunable luminescence. In the framework of this study, we have investigated lanthanide-based coordination polymers with 4,5-dichlorophthalate as a ligand ().
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For more than a decade, there has been growing interest in lanthanide-based coordination compounds, particularly because of their interesting optical properties. Our group, which has been involved in that field for almost 20 years, has currently focused its attention on luminescent heterolanthanide coordination polymers that could be used as taggants for the fight against counterfeiting. Evidently, because technological applications are targeted, ligands must be commercially available, have low cost, and be thermally stable and nontoxic. Moreover, the production process must be respectful of the environment. Therefore, we have investigated numerous benzenepolycarboxylate ligands in association with lanthanide ions, with the aim of bright and highly tunable luminescence. In the framework of this study, we have investigated lanthanide-based coordination polymers with 4,5-dichlorophthalate as a ligand ().

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, there has been no lanthanide-based coordination polymer with this ligand reported so far. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that the presence of a substituent on the phenyl ring hardly affects the luminescent properties of lanthanide-based coordination polymers. Finally, chlorinated ligands are well-known for their efficiency as flame retardants, which could constitute an asset for technological applications.

elements.content: 4,5-Dichlorophthalic acid was purchased from TCI (98%) and used without further purification. It was recrystallized in water, and its crystal structure was solved. Crystal and final structure refinement data are given in Table S1. A projection view of an asymmetric unit is shown in Figure S1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Characterization of the Ligand

4,5-Dichlorophthalic acid was purchased from TCI (98%) and used without further purification. It was recrystallized in water, and its crystal structure was solved. Crystal and final structure refinement data are given in Table S1. A projection view of an asymmetric unit is shown in Figure S1.

elements.content: Two equivalents of sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid. The resulting clear solution was evaporated to dryness and the solid residue dissolved in ethanol and refluxed for 1 h to ensure complete dissolution of impurities. Precipitation was provoked by addition of ethoxyethane. The obtained solid was filtered and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was about 90%. By recrystallization, single crystals of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. Crystal and final structure refinement data are given in Table S2. A projection view of an asymmetric unit is shown in Figure S2.
elements.clean_text: Two equivalents of sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid. The resulting clear solution was evaporated to dryness and the solid residue dissolved in ethanol and refluxed for 1 h to ensure complete dissolution of impurities. By recrystallization, single crystals of Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. Crystal and final structure refinement data are given in Table S2. A projection view of an asymmetric unit is shown in Figure S2.

elements.content: A comparison between the simulated powder diffraction pattern from this crystal structure and the experimental powder diffraction diagram of the microcrystalline powder evidences that the microcrystalline powder and the single crystals are isostructural (Figure S3). This was supported by a thermal analysis of the microcrystalline powder (Figure S4), which shows the departure of four water molecules per formula unit.
elements.clean_text: A comparison between the simulated powder diffraction pattern from this crystal structure and the experimental powder diffraction diagram of the microcrystalline powder evidences that the microcrystalline powder and the single crystals are isostructural (Figure S3). This was supported by a thermal analysis of the microcrystalline powder (Figure S4), which shows the departure of four water molecules per formula unit.

elements.content: Anal. Calcd (found) for Na2(dcpa)·4H2O (C8H10Cl2Na2O8; MW = 351 g·mol–1): C, 27.4 (27.4); H, 2.9 (2.8); Cl, 20.0 (20.2); Na, 13.1 (13.0); O, 36.6 (36.6). The infrared spectrum presents the characteristic peak of a protonated carboxylate function (1405 cm–1) (Figure S5). The liquid-state UV–visible absorption spectrum of a dilute aqueous solution of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O (C = 6.8 × 10–5 mol L–1) was recorded (Figure S6). It shows two maxima centered at 282 and 292 nm, respectively. Molar absorption coefficients have been calculated at both wavelengths: ε282nm = 680 cm–1 mol–1 L and ε292nm = 560 cm–1 mol–1 L.

elements.content: Lanthanide oxides (4N) were purchased from AMPERE and used without further purification. Chloride salts were prepared according to established procedures. Aqueous solutions of a lanthanide chloride (0.5 mmol in 20 mL) on one hand and of the sodium salt of 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid (0.75 mmol in 20 mL) on the other hand were mixed at room temperature and stirred for 3 days. Precipitation progressively occurred. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried in ambient air. The yield was about 90%. On the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction data, the coordination polymers were classified into two families of isostructural compounds. (i) The first series constitutes coordination polymers based on the lightest lanthanide ions (La3+–Gd3+ except Pm3+). Despite great efforts, it has not been possible, to date, to obtain single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, the crystal structures of these compounds are still unknown. (ii) The second series gathers coordination polymers based on the heaviest lanthanide ions (Tb3+–Lu3+, Y3+). These compounds have been assumed to be isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ (Figure S7), whose crystal structure is described hereafter. Chemical analyses of these compounds are reported in Table S3. IR spectra of these compounds have been obtained (see Figure S8 for an example). Infrared spectra present the characteristic peak of a protonated carboxylate function (1421 cm–1).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of the Microcrystalline Powders of the Lanthanide-Based Coordination Polymers

Lanthanide oxides (4N) were purchased from AMPERE and used without further purification. Chloride salts were prepared according to established procedures. Aqueous solutions of a lanthanide chloride (0.5 mmol in 20 mL) on one hand and of the sodium salt of 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid (0.75 mmol in 20 mL) on the other hand were mixed at room temperature and stirred for 3 days. Precipitation progressively occurred. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried in ambient air. The yield was about 90%. On the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction data, the coordination polymers were classified into two families of isostructural compounds. (i) The first series constitutes coordination polymers based on the lightest lanthanide ions (La3+-Gd3+ except Pm3+). Despite great efforts, it has not been possible, to date, to obtain single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, the crystal structures of these compounds are still unknown. (ii) The second series gathers coordination polymers based on the heaviest lanthanide ions (Tb3+-Lu3+, Y3+). These compounds have been assumed to be isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ (Figure S7), whose crystal structure is described hereafter. Chemical analyses of these compounds are reported in Table S3. IR spectra of these compounds have been obtained (see Figure S8 for an example). Infrared spectra present the characteristic peak of a protonated carboxylate function (1421 cm-1).

elements.content: It has been demonstrated that, because of their similar chemical properties, it is possible to substitute one lanthanide ion with another and therefore to obtain hetero-lanthanide coordination polymers when both corresponding homolanthanide coordination polymers present the same crystal structure. Some hetero-lanthanide coordination polymers have been prepared in the framework of this study. Their synthesis is the same as that described for homo-lanthanide compounds. The only difference is that the aqueous lanthanide chloride solution is replaced by an aqueous solution of the appropriate mixture of lanthanide chlorides. Relative ratios between the different lanthanide ions have been estimated by SEM measurements (see Table S4).

elements.content: Tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. It was jellified according to established procedures. Dilute aqueous solutions of erbium chloride (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on one hand and of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on the other hand were allowed to diffuse slowly through a TMOS gel medium (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. Needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination appeared after a few weeks ().
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Single Crystals of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ 

Tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. It was jellified according to established procedures. Dilute aqueous solutions of erbium chloride (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on one hand and of Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on the other hand were allowed to diffuse slowly through a TMOS gel medium (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. Needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination appeared after a few weeks ().

elements.content: A single crystal of H2(dcpa) was mounted on a Kappa CCD Bruker diffractometer, and those of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O and [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ were mounted on an APEXII AXS-Bruker diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and cell refinements were performed with the Denzo and Scalepack programs. The crystal structures have been solved by direct methods using the SIR97 program and refined with full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 (SHELX97) with the WINGX program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were located at ideal positions. Hydrogen atoms of the water molecules were not located except in the crystal structure of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O. Crystal and final structure refinement data of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ are given in . Full details of the X-ray structure determination of the crystal structures of H2(dcpa), Na2(dcpa)·4H2O, and [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under the depository numbers CCDC-1577921, CCDC-1577920, and CCDC-229478, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

A single crystal of H2(dcpa) was mounted on a Kappa CCD Bruker diffractometer, and those of Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O and [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ were mounted on an APEXII AXS-Bruker diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and cell refinements were performed with the Denzo and Scalepack programs. The crystal structures have been solved by direct methods using the SIR97 program and refined with full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 (SHELX97) with the WINGX program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were located at ideal positions. Hydrogen atoms of the water molecules were not located except in the crystal structure of Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O. Crystal and final structure refinement data of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ are given in . Full details of the X-ray structure determination of the crystal structures of H2(dcpa), Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O, and [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under the depository numbers CCDC-1577921, CCDC-1577920, and CCDC-229478, respectively.

Experimental diagrams have been collected with a Panalytical X’pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X’Celerator detector. Temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction diagrams (TDXD) have been collected (between room temperature and 1000 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere) with the same diffractometer equipped with an Anton Parr HTK 1200 furnace. Simulated patterns from crystal structures were produced with POWDERCELL and WINPLOTR software programs. Pattern indexing was performed by the programs McMaille and Checkcell.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Experimental diagrams have been collected with a Panalytical X'pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X'Celerator detector. Temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction diagrams (TDXD) have been collected (between room temperature and 1000 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere) with the same diffractometer equipped with an Anton Parr HTK 1200 furnace. Simulated patterns from crystal structures were produced with POWDERCELL and WINPLOTR software programs. Pattern indexing was performed by the programs McMaille and Checkcell.

elements.content: Solid-state emission and excitation spectra have been measured on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a 450 W Xe lamp, a UV–vis photomultiplier (Hamamatsu R928, sensitivity 190–860 nm), and an infrared photodiode cooled by nitrogen liquid (InGaAs, sensitivity 800–1600 nm). Most of the luminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature. Quantum yield measurements were performed using a Jobin-Yvon integrating sphere (Φ = (E c – E a)/(L a – L c), with E c being the integrated emission spectrum of the sample, E a the integrated “blank” emission spectrum, L a the “blank” absorption, and L c the sample absorption at the excitation wavelength). The emission/excitation spectra and quantum yield recordings were realized on powder samples introduced in cylindrical quartz cells of 0.7 cm diameter and 2.4 cm height, which were placed directly inside the integrating sphere. The infrared emissions were measured directly on powder samples introduced in quartz capillary tubes. The phospholuminescence of the Y-based microcrystalline powder has been measured at 77 K. The sample was introduced in a quartz capillary tube, which was placed inside a small Dewar that contained liquid nitrogen. Luminescence decays were been measured at room temperature using this apparatus with a Xe flash lamp (phosphorescence mode). Lifetimes and quantum yields are averages of three independent determinations.

Most of the luminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature. The emission/excitation spectra and quantum yield recordings were realized on powder samples introduced in cylindrical quartz cells of 0.7 cm diameter and 2.4 cm height, which were placed directly inside the integrating sphere. elements.content: Comparative solid-state luminescence spectra have been measured on the same Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer on powder samples shaped into pellets. Spectra were recorded between 450 and 725 nm under identical operating conditions and without turning the lamp off to ensure a valid comparison between the emission spectra.

elements.content: Luminescence intensities of the samples expressed in Cd m–2 were measured with a Gigahertz-Optik X1-1 optometer with an integration time of 200 ms on 1.5 cm2 pellets. The intensity of the UV flux at the sample location, 0.9 mW cm–2, was measured with a VilberLourmat VLX-3W radiometer. [Tb2(bdc)3·4H2O]∞, where bdc2– stands for terephthalate, was used as a standard. Its luminance is 131 Cd m–2 under these operating conditions (λexc 312 nm; flux 0.9 mW cm–2).

elements.content: The CIE (Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage) (x, y) emission color coordinates were obtained using a MSU-003 colorimeter (Majantys) with the PhotonProbe 1.6.0 Software (Majantys). Color measurements: 2°, CIE 1931, step 5 nm, under 312 nm UV light. X = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × x λ, Y = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × y λ, and Z = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × z λ with k constant for the measurement system I λ (sample spectrum intensity), wavelength dependence (x λ, y λ, z λ), and trichromatic values (x = X/(X + Y + Z), y = Y/(X + Y + Z), and z = Z/(X + Y + Z). Mean xyz values are given for each sample, which act as light sources (luminescent samples). Standards from Phosphor Technology used, calibrated at 312 nm: red phosphor Gd2O2S:Eu (x = 0.667, y = 0.330) and green phosphor Gd2O2S:Tb (x = 0.328, y = 0.537).

Colorimetric Measurements

The CIE (Commission Internationale de l'Eclairage) (x, y) emission color coordinates were obtained using a MSU-003 colorimeter (Majantys) with the PhotonProbe 1.6.0 Software (Majantys). Color measurements: 2°, CIE 1931, step 5 nm, under 312 nm UV light. X = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × x λ, Y = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × y λ, and Z = k × ∫380nm 780nm I λ × z λ with k constant for the measurement system I λ (sample spectrum intensity), wavelength dependence (x λ, y λ, z λ), and trichromatic values (x = X/(X + Y + Z), y = Y/(X + Y + Z), and z = Z/(X + Y + Z). Mean xyz values are given for each sample, which act as light sources (luminescent samples). Standards from Phosphor Technology used, calibrated at 312 nm: red phosphor Gd2O2S:Eu (x = 0.667, y = 0.330) and green phosphor Gd2O2S:Tb (x = 0.328, y = 0.537).

elements.content: Thermal analyses (TGA/DSC) were performed using a STA6000 PerkinElmer thermal analyzer. The sample was analyzed between 30 and 970 °C with a 20 °C/min heating rate, under a dinitrogen atmosphere (100 mL.min–1) in ceramic crucibles.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

Thermal analyses (TGA/DSC) were performed using a STA6000 PerkinElmer thermal analyzer. The sample was analyzed between 30 and 970 °C with a 20 °C/min heating rate, under a dinitrogen atmosphere (100 mL.min-1) in ceramic crucibles.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the Gaussian 09 program. The ωB97XD functional and 6-311+G* atomic basis set were employed. The three different (dcpa)2– structural arrangements (hereafter denoted dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3, respectively) can be extracted from the crystal structure of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ obtained by X-ray diffraction techniques. They can be mainly differentiated by the dihedral angles formed by the phenyl ring average plane and the two carboxylate planes ( and ). Missing hydrogen atoms were added to the phenyl ring, and their positions were optimized, while the rest of the atomic positions were kept frozen. These constraints allow mimicking the metal coordination and crystal-packing constraints onto the (dcpa)2– optical properties on comparison to the free (dcpa)2– molecule. Indeed, their geometries were optimized to obtain a reference-free geometry. The three geometry optimizations converged to the same arrangement, hereafter denoted dcpaFREE. Harmonic vibrational frequency calculations were performed for dcpaFREE to confirm that the optimized structural arrangement corresponds to a stationary point on the potential energy surface. The Cartesian coordinates and relative energies of dcpaFREE, dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3 are given in Table S5. Time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations were performed to compute vertical transition energies, allowing access to the energies of the first singlet and triplet excited states.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the Gaussian 09 program. The ωB97XD functional and 6-311+G* atomic basis set were employed. The three different (dcpa)2- structural arrangements (hereafter denoted dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3, respectively) can be extracted from the crystal structure of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ obtained by X-ray diffraction techniques. They can be mainly differentiated by the dihedral angles formed by the phenyl ring average plane and the two carboxylate planes ( and ). Missing hydrogen atoms were added to the phenyl ring, and their positions were optimized, while the rest of the atomic positions were kept frozen. These constraints allow mimicking the metal coordination and crystal-packing constraints onto the (dcpa)2- optical properties on comparison to the free (dcpa)2- molecule. Indeed, their geometries were optimized to obtain a reference-free geometry. The three geometry optimizations converged to the same arrangement, hereafter denoted dcpaFREE. Harmonic vibrational frequency calculations were performed for dcpaFREE to confirm that the optimized structural arrangement corresponds to a stationary point on the potential energy surface. The Cartesian coordinates and relative energies of dcpaFREE, dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3 are given in Table S5. Time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations were performed to compute vertical transition energies, allowing access to the energies of the first singlet and triplet excited states.

Results and Discussion

Reactions in water of one of the heaviest lanthanide ions (Tb3+–Lu3+ or Y3+) with the sodium salt of 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid (Na2dcpa·4H2O) lead to a series of isostructural compounds (Figure S7) with the general chemical formula [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞, where Ln = Tb–Lu, Y. The crystal structure has been solved on the basis of the Er-based compound. Isostructurality of the other compounds has been assumed on the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction diagrams (Figure S7). [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ can be described as a juxtaposition of molecular planes decorated by Cl atoms ().

elements.content: These planes that spread parallel to the (a,b) plane can be described as an alternation of two types of inorganic chains that spread along the a axis: the first inorganic chain involves only Er1 atoms, while the second inorganic chain involves only Er2 atoms. Er1 atoms are nine-coordinated by five oxygen atoms that belong to three different carboxylate functions from three different (dcpa)2– ligands and four oxygen atoms from coordination water molecules that form a slightly distorted tricapped trigonal prism. Er2 is only eight-coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from five carboxylate functions that belong to five different (dcpa)2– ligands and one oxygen atom from a coordination water molecule that form a slightly distorted dodecahedron. (dcpa)2– ligands adopt three different coordination modes, as seen in .

elements.content: Lanthanide ions that belong to the same molecular plane are very close to each other (between 4.7 and 6 Å) (). In contrast, the shortest intermetallic distances between lanthanide ions that belong to adjacent molecular planes are greater than 13 Å (). Because of these uncommonly large interplane distances, intermetallic energy transfers between lanthanide ions that belong to different molecular planes are expected to be weak, while those between lanthanide ions that belong to the same molecular plane must be efficient. The stability of the crystal packing is ensured by hydrogen bonds that involve crystallization and coordination water molecules, π–π interactions between adjacent phenyl rings, aand halogen bonds that induce the quite large space between molecular planes (d Cl–Cl ≃ 4 Å) ().

elements.content: A careful analysis of the three independent ligand geometries indicates that they are quite similar. Indeed, in the three cases dihedral angles between the phenyl ring and the two carboxylate groups are very different ( and ). In the three arrangements, dihedral angles for the bidentate carboxylate functions are 7.6, 3.3, and 8.5°, respectively, for dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3 while for monodentate and bridging carboxylate functions, they are 86.6, 99.9, and 94.1°, respectively. Therefore, they show important geometrical differences in comparison to the free molecule dcpaFREE obtained by DFT calculations (see ). For the latter, the two dihedral angles formed by the phenyl ring average plane and the two carboxylate planes are both equal to 50.2°. These differences clearly indicate that, despite quite weak intermolecular bonds, constraints applied by the crystal packing onto the ligand imply important rotations of the carboxylate groups.

elements.content: Coupled TGA and DSC analyses of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ have been performed (). They show first a double endothermic weight loss between room temperature and 150 °C that can be attributed to the departure of the three coordination water molecules for the first loss and the five coordination water molecules for the second loss. Then the resulting dehydrated phase remains stable up to 400 °C. This was confirmed by temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S9). The dehydrated phase is crystalline, but up to now we have not succeeded in characterizing its crystal structure. When it is exposed to a wet atmosphere, the anhydrous compound does not rehydrate. Above 400 °C, decomposition of the ligand (dcpa)2– occurs and leads finally to erbium oxide.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

Coupled TGA and DSC analyses of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ have been performed (). They show first a double endothermic weight loss between room temperature and 150 °C that can be attributed to the departure of the three coordination water molecules for the first loss and the five coordination water molecules for the second loss. Then the resulting dehydrated phase remains stable up to 400 °C. This was confirmed by temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S9). The dehydrated phase is crystalline, but up to now we have not succeeded in characterizing its crystal structure. When it is exposed to a wet atmosphere, the anhydrous compound does not rehydrate. Above 400 °C, decomposition of the ligand (dcpa)2- occurs and leads finally to erbium oxide.

elements.content: Solid-state excitation and luminescence spectra of [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ with Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er have been recorded (). Excitation spectra for Tb­(III) and Dy­(III) show a broad band with a maximum at 302 nm, which demonstrates that the ligand presents an efficient “antenna effect” toward these lanthanide ions. Energy levels of the first excited singlet and triplet states have been estimated by referring respectively to the UV–vis absorption edge (315 nm ≃ 31750 cm–1) and to the shortest wavelength of the phosphorescence band (400 nm ≃ 25000 cm–1) of [Y2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ (Figures S10 and S11). Therefore, the gap between the energy levels of the first singlet and triplet excited states is ΔE(1π* → 3π*) ≃ 6750 cm–1. This is in agreement with Latva’s and Reinhoudt’s empirical rules which state that intersystem crossing is efficient when the gap between these two energy levels is greater than 5000 cm–1. It is also notable that the observed phosphorescence lifetime of [Y2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ is very long (τobs = 59(1) ms) in comparison with other lanthanide-based coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Luminescence of [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er

Solid-state excitation and luminescence spectra of [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er have been recorded (). Excitation spectra for Tb(III) and Dy(III) show a broad band with a maximum at 302 nm, which demonstrates that the ligand presents an efficient "antenna effect" toward these lanthanide ions. Energy levels of the first excited singlet and triplet states have been estimated by referring respectively to the UV-vis absorption edge (315 nm ≃ 31750 cm-1) and to the shortest wavelength of the phosphorescence band (400 nm ≃ 25000 cm-1) of [Y2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞  (Figures S10 and S11). Therefore, the gap between the energy levels of the first singlet and triplet excited states is ΔE(1π* → 3π*) ≃ 6750 cm-1. This is in agreement with Latva's and Reinhoudt's empirical rules which state that intersystem crossing is efficient when the gap between these two energy levels is greater than 5000 cm-1. It is also notable that the observed phosphorescence lifetime of [Y2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ is very long (τobs = 59(1) ms) in comparison with other lanthanide-based coordination polymers.

elements.content: TD-DFT calculations have been performed in order to estimate the energy of the first singlet and triplet excited states for each of the three ligand arrangements encountered in the crystal structure (). Oscillator strengths of the singlet excited states have been calculated. In the absence of spin–orbit coupling in the calculation, oscillator strengths associated with the triplet excited states are equal to zero since they are spin-forbidden. These calculations indicate that absorptions of the first singlet excited states are very low for the crystal arrangements dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3 (oscillator strengths are about 10–3). This is not the case for the dcpaFREE arrangement. Interestingly, the second singlet excited states of dcpa1, dcpa2, and dcpa3, which lie much higher in energy than the first states (energy differences between first and second singlet excited states are between 3750 and 4100 cm–1), show much higher oscillator strengths. Those are directly related to the absorbance.

This suggests that intersystem crossing occurs between the second singlet excited states and the first triplet excited states that are separated by about 5400–5800 cm–1 (). However, recent improvements in time-resolved spectroscopy have revealed much more complex optical de-excitation schemes in a great number of cases where excited states higher than the first singlet and triplet excited states are involved.

elements.content: Excitation spectrum of the Tb-based compound () shows a very efficient antenna effect which is in agreement with Latva’s empirical rule which predicts that the energy of the lowest excited triplet state (25000 cm–1) favors an efficient ligand to metal energy transfer without significant back-transfer. also shows the emission upon UV irradiation (λexc 302 nm) with the seven classical narrow bands from Tb­(III) that are attributed to the transitions 5F4 → 7F6, 7F5, 7F4, 7F3, 7F2, 7F1, and 7F0 centered at 490, 542.5, 585, 621.5, 648.5, 669, and 680 nm, respectively. The overall quantum yield (Q Tb Ligand = 32.6(2)%) and observed luminescent lifetime (τobs = 0.97(1) ms) under UV light (λexc 302 nm) are quite large and compare well with values that were obtained in previous studies. Despite very short intermetallic distances in the molecular motif, a sizable luminescence intensity under UV light (λexc 312 nm) has been measured (153(4) Cd m–2 under a 0.9 mW cm–2 luminous flux). To the best of our knowledge, only few coordination polymers exhibit higher luminance under similar operating conditions.

elements.content: Excitation spectrum of the Dy-based compound reveals a classical broad band at high energy corresponding to the (dcpa)2– ligand, stimulating a lower antenna effect in comparison to the Tb-based compound. Because of its small energy gap the Dy-based compound presents a much weaker luminescence under UV light (λexc 302 nm) than the Tb-based compound. The emission spectrum shows the classical four bands from Dy­(III) that are attributed to the transitions 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 6H13/2, 6H11/2, and 6H9/2 centered at 478.5, 573.5, 660.5, and 751 nm, respectively. A relatively low overall quantum yield (Q Dy Ligand = 0.16(1)%) has been measured. The observed luminescent lifetime cannot be measured for Dy­(III) with our current setup because the lifetime for Dy­(III) is lower than 20 μs (the limit of the flash lamp and spectrometer).

elements.content: The excitation spectrum for the Ho-based compound is particularly weak in comparison to Tb- and Dy-based compounds and does not reveal any characteristic band from the (dcpa)2– ligand. Visible emission has been measured; the usual red band from Ho­(III) centered at 659.5 nm is observed, attributed to the transitions 5F3 → 5I7 and 5F5 → 5I8. An additional band in the visible region is observed at 538 nm, which is assigned to the transition 5F4 ↔ 5I8. The particularity of this transition is that it is observed by a dip corresponding to internal holmium-centered reabsorption of the broad residual ligand-centered 1π* → 1π emission (Figure S12). An infrared band centered at 977 nm, assigned to the transitions 5F5 → 5I7 and 5F4 → 5I6, has also been observed.

elements.content: For the Er­(III) compound, the emission spectrum reveals a low transition with a maximum at 557 nm and a shoulder at 542 nm, which can be attributed to the transitions 2H9/2, 2G9/2, 4F9/2 → 4I13/2, and 4S3/2 → 4I15/2 respectively, characteristic of a weak green emission of erbium­(III). At higher energy, some dips are observed as in the erbium­(III) compound; all dips are characteristic of the internal erbium-centered reabsorption of the broad residual ligand-centered 1π* → 1π emission (2H11/2, 4F7/2, (4F5/2, 4F3/2) ↔ 4I15/2 at 520, 488, and 453 nm, respectively). The characteristic infrared emission of Er­(III) has been also observed at 77 K at approximately 1536 nm, showing the transition 4I13/2 → 4I15/2.

elements.content: A series of heterolanthanide compounds with general chemical formula [Tb2–2x Y2x (dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 has been prepared. On the basis of their powder diffraction all of the compounds of the series have been assumed to be isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ (Figure S13). The composition of the compounds has been estimated on the basis of SEM measurements (Table S4). Luminescence spectra have been recorded and their integrated intensities calculated ().

A series of heterolanthanide compounds with general chemical formula [Tb2-2x Y2x (dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 has been prepared. On the basis of their powder diffraction all of the compounds of the series have been assumed to be isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ (Figure S13). The composition of the compounds has been estimated on the basis of SEM measurements (Table S4). Luminescence spectra have been recorded and their integrated intensities calculated ().

elements.content: As expected, these spectra clearly show that dilution of Tb3+ ions by optically nonactive Y3+ ions provokes an enhancement of the luminescence of the Tb3+ ions. The more intense luminescence is observed for [Tb0.2Y1.8(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞: that is, x = 0.9. This value is in good agreement with the empirical rule which states that intermetallic energy transfers are less efficient when lanthanide ions are more than 10 Å away from each other. Indeed, this crystal structure can be described as the superimposition of molecular layers that are separated by more than 13 Å. In contrast, in a molecular layer, each lanthanide ion is surrounded by 10 other lanthanide ions which are less than 10 Å from it (). Therefore, according to this quite rough model, luminescence intensity is expected to reach a maximum for x = 0.91.

Hetero-lanthanide compounds with general chemical formula [Tb2-2x Eu2x (dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 have also been prepared. Their composition has been estimated on the basis of SEM measurements (Table S4). Powder X-ray diffraction diagrams show that compounds with x ≤ 0.5 are isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ (Figure S14), while those with x ≥ 0.6 are isostructural with the lightest lanthanide-based compounds.

elements.content: In the following, we have focused our attention on compounds with x ≤ 0.5 because of their isostructurality with the reported crystal structure. Because intermetallic distances between lanthanide ions that belong to the same molecular plane are short, intermetallic energy transfers are expected to be efficient and therefore it must be possible to observe a sizable Tb3+ to Eu3+ intermetallic energy transfer. Accordingly, this may provide access to red luminescence in this family of compounds, despite the fact that the Eu-based compound does not belong to the series of compounds isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞. Indeed, excitation spectra () show that the characteristic peak of Tb3+ centered at 542 nm (5D4 → 7F5) abruptly decreases and almost disappears as soon as x becomes greater than 0.2. At the same time, the characteristic peak of Eu3+ centered at 615 nm (5D0 → 7F2) increases and reaches a maximum at x = 0.1 and then decreases slowly although the Eu3+ content increases. This suggests that feeding of the luminescent levels of the Eu3+ ions is more efficient via a two-step ligand to Tb3+ to Eu3+ energy transfer in comparison to that from a direct ligand to Eu3+ transfer. This was unexpected and, to the best of our knowledge, has never been reported before.

elements.content: Terbium to Europium energy transfer efficiency (ηET) can be estimated by using the relationship η ET = 1 − τ obs τ 0 where τobs and τ0 are the luminescent lifetimes measured in the presence and in the absence of an acceptor ion. Therefore, excitation and emission spectra of [Tb1.6Eu0.4(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ and [Tb1.6Y0.4(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ (Figures S15 and S16, respectively) have been recorded and their overall quantum yields (QLn3+ Ligand) and luminescent lifetimes measured. They are given in . Additionally, excitation and emission spectra of [Y1.6Eu0.4(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞, which is isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ (Figure S17 and Table S4), have also been recorded (Figure S18) and overall quantum yield and luminescent lifetimes measured ().

clearly shows that the Tb3+ to Eu3+ intermetallic energy transfer is particularly efficient in these compounds: Q Tb3+ Ligand decreases from approximately 80% to 3% when Y3+ is replaced by Eu3+ and Q Eu3+ Ligand stays stable at around 15% when Y3+ is replaced by Tb3+. Terbium to europium energy transfer efficiency (ηET) can be estimated as 77% according to . This high value makes the feeding of the luminescent energy level of Eu3+ ions as efficient via Tb3+ to Eu3+ intermetallic energy transfer as by a direct ligand to Eu3+ “antenna effect”. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to evaluate intrinsic quantum yields for Tb3+ ions or for Eu3+ ions. This can probably be related to the first singlet excited states that overlap with 4f–4f absorption bands centered at 379 nm for Tb3+ and 395 nm for Eu3+. Indeed, even if absorption bands of the ligand are weak, they are stronger than the forbidden 4f–4f transitions.

Hetero-Lanthanide Coordination Polymer [Y1.8Nd0.2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with Emission in the IR Region

These results show that light lanthanides can be incorporated in this system, provided their doping rates remain reasonably low. In order to test the IR-emitting capability of this system, [Y1.8Nd0.2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ was prepared. Because of its high Y3+ content, this compound is isostructural with [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ (Figure S19 and Table S4). Its excitation and emission spectra have been recorded () at room temperature.

elements.content: The excitation spectrum indicates that dcpa2– has an efficient “antenna effect” toward Nthe d3+ ion. The emission spectrum shows the classical emission bands from Nd­(III) that are attributed to the transitions 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4I11/2, and 4I13/2 centered at 900, 1065, and 1334 nm, respectively. The excitation spectrum shows some thin bands between 350 and 825 nm corresponding to the f–f transitions for Nd­(III), as shown in . This sizable emission in the IR region is particularly interesting as far as multiemission luminescent materials are concerned. Indeed, it opens the way to heteropoly-lanthanide coordination polymers that would emit in both the visible and the IR domains under a unique UV irradiation. Because of their potential technical applications in the field of luminescent barcodes, multiemissive coordination compounds have aroused great interest in recent years and several interesting compounds have been reported. However, either emission modulation was induced by varying excitation wavelength or emission was restricted to a sharp emission wavelength range. To the best of our knowledge, examples of coordination compounds that can simultaneously (that is, under the same excitation radiation) emit both in IR and visible regions are scarce.

elements.content: These spectra (Figures S21 and S22) confirm that the dcpa2– ligand can have an efficient “antenna effect” toward Eu3+, Tb3+, and Nd3+. The emission spectrum presents the characteristic peaks of the three optically active lanthanide ions, that is 615 nm for Eu3+, 542 nm for Tb3+, and 1062 nm for Nd3+, with sizable intensities. This validates the fact that some compounds of this series can be interesting as far as luminescent barcodes stretching over a large emission wavelength range are concerned.

elements.content: A new series of isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers has been synthesized. Homo-lanthanide coordination polymers that belong to this family have the general chemical formula [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ with Ln = Tb–Lu, Y, and some of them exhibit intense luminescence. This series can be extended to hetero-lanthanide compounds by mixing two or more of these heavier lanthanide ions, as has often been reported previously. The originality of this series lies in two points: first, it is possible to extend the family to hetero-lanthanide coordination compounds that involve some light lanthanide ions in a reasonable doping rate; second, some of the lightest lanthanide-containing compounds exhibit quite intense luminescence in the IR region, as exemplified by the Nd-based compounds described above. This makes possible the design of Eu-Tb-Nd-based compounds that present efficient emission in both the visible and IR regions under a unique excitation wavelength. This is of great interest as far as luminescent barcodes are concerned. This strategy also relies on the use of lanthanide ions, such as Y3+, that on one hand impose the crystal structure and on the other hand prevent intermetallic quenching. An extremely wide variety of such compounds could be synthesized in the near future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Outlook

A new series of isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers has been synthesized. Homo-lanthanide coordination polymers that belong to this family have the general chemical formula [Ln2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ with Ln = Tb-Lu, Y, and some of them exhibit intense luminescence. This series can be extended to hetero-lanthanide compounds by mixing two or more of these heavier lanthanide ions, as has often been reported previously. The originality of this series lies in two points: first, it is possible to extend the family to hetero-lanthanide coordination compounds that involve some light lanthanide ions in a reasonable doping rate; second, some of the lightest lanthanide-containing compounds exhibit quite intense luminescence in the IR region, as exemplified by the Nd-based compounds described above. This makes possible the design of Eu-Tb-Nd-based compounds that present efficient emission in both the visible and IR regions under a unique excitation wavelength. This is of great interest as far as luminescent barcodes are concerned. This strategy also relies on the use of lanthanide ions, such as Y3+, that on one hand impose the crystal structure and on the other hand prevent intermetallic quenching. An extremely wide variety of such compounds could be synthesized in the near future.

cln_elements.content: Tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. It was jellified according to established procedures. Dilute aqueous solutions of erbium chloride (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on one hand and of Na2(dcpa)·4H2O (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on the other hand were allowed to diffuse slowly through a TMOS gel medium (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. Needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination appeared after a few weeks ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Single Crystals of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ 

Tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. It was jellified according to established procedures. Dilute aqueous solutions of erbium chloride (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on one hand and of Na2(dcpa)⋅4H2O (1/4 mmol in 10 mL) on the other hand were allowed to diffuse slowly through a TMOS gel medium (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. Needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray structure determination appeared after a few weeks ().

cln_elements.content: Coupled TGA and DSC analyses of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5·3H2O]∞ have been performed (). They show first a double endothermic weight loss between room temperature and 150 °C that can be attributed to the departure of the three coordination water molecules for the first loss and the five coordination water molecules for the second loss. Then the resulting dehydrated phase remains stable up to 400 °C. This was confirmed by temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S9). The dehydrated phase is crystalline, but up to now we have not succeeded in characterizing its crystal structure. When it is exposed to a wet atmosphere, the anhydrous compound does not rehydrate. Above 400 °C, decomposition of the ligand (dcpa)2– occurs and leads finally to erbium oxide.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

Coupled TGA and DSC analyses of [Er2(dcpa)3(H2O)5⋅3H2O]∞ have been performed (). They show first a double endothermic weight loss between room temperature and 150 °C that can be attributed to the departure of the three coordination water molecules for the first loss and the five coordination water molecules for the second loss. Then the resulting dehydrated phase remains stable up to 400 °C. This was confirmed by temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S9). The dehydrated phase is crystalline, but up to now we have not succeeded in characterizing its crystal structure. When it is exposed to a wet atmosphere, the anhydrous compound does not rehydrate. Above 400 °C, decomposition of the ligand (dcpa)2- occurs and leads finally to erbium oxide.
